episodes.title: NIST 800-171 Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.692
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.692 --> 00:00:09.167
Hi and thanks for
joining us here at Bizpro.TV.

3
00:00:09.167 --> 00:00:10.710
I'm Joshua Marpet.

4
00:00:10.710 --> 00:00:13.090
This is Scott Lyons and
we're with Red Lion.

5
00:00:13.090 --> 00:00:17.560
We're here to talk to you
today about Nist 800-171 and

6
00:00:17.560 --> 00:00:19.630
getting the basics of it down pat.

7
00:00:19.630 --> 00:00:21.210
So Scott,
why don't you tell them about yourself.

8
00:00:21.210 --> 00:00:22.210
>> Sure thing.

9
00:00:22.210 --> 00:00:23.430
So hi everybody.

10
00:00:23.430 --> 00:00:25.300
I am the CEO of Red Lion.

11
00:00:25.300 --> 00:00:31.270
I am a graduate of the business of,
geez, I can't even speak right now.

12
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:35.230
The school of hard knocks when
it comes to business, right?

13
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:39.500
I am a peer review on SYNACK
the Info Sec journal.

14
00:00:39.500 --> 00:00:42.440
I do hold certifications although
I won't tell you which, right?

15
00:00:42.440 --> 00:00:44.730
And my real passion are people and
business.

16
00:00:44.730 --> 00:00:45.230
Josh.

17
00:00:46.420 --> 00:00:49.940
>> So my name's Joshua Marpet, I'm the COO
of Red Lion, Chief Operating Officer.

18
00:00:49.940 --> 00:00:52.410
I've been around the block more than once.

19
00:00:52.410 --> 00:00:53.690
You've probably heard me say this but

20
00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:57.265
I'm an ex-cop, I'm an ex-fireman, I'm
an ex horse dentist, I'm an ex-blacksmith.

21
00:00:57.265 --> 00:00:59.840
N,o that's not a joke, that's actually me.

22
00:00:59.840 --> 00:01:01.260
I've been a jail guard,

23
00:01:01.260 --> 00:01:06.430
I've done just about everything except
astronaut, and I'm working on that.

24
00:01:06.430 --> 00:01:07.341
>> Wow.
>> Okay, so

25
00:01:07.341 --> 00:01:12.480
I run Security BSides Delaware
along with Janice Paulson.

26
00:01:12.480 --> 00:01:15.902
And occasionally I get to sleep,
it's an amazing thing, so.

27
00:01:15.902 --> 00:01:19.850
>> So today let's talk about
what we're getting into, right?

28
00:01:19.850 --> 00:01:23.760
So, we're dealing with the 171, okay.

29
00:01:23.760 --> 00:01:25.990
We need to know who is NIST?

30
00:01:25.990 --> 00:01:28.530
We need to know what the heck 171 is.

31
00:01:28.530 --> 00:01:32.173
How does it translate to entities
that deal with the government?

32
00:01:32.173 --> 00:01:34.455
How does it change process?

33
00:01:34.455 --> 00:01:38.050
How does it change the certification,
right?

34
00:01:38.050 --> 00:01:39.394
What is the certification?

35
00:01:39.394 --> 00:01:41.108
What is the cost associated?

36
00:01:41.108 --> 00:01:45.710
And some other general Q and A about 171.

37
00:01:45.710 --> 00:01:47.770
So let's start of with NIST.

38
00:01:47.770 --> 00:01:50.260
NIST is the National Institute
of Standards and

39
00:01:50.260 --> 00:01:55.960
Technology it is developed by the US
Department of Commerce, founded in 1901.

40
00:01:55.960 --> 00:01:58.280
NIST is responsible for

41
00:01:58.280 --> 00:02:02.920
a lot of the major certification projects
that you'll find with the US Government.

42
00:02:02.920 --> 00:02:05.990
From 5g wireless standards to Biopharms

43
00:02:05.990 --> 00:02:11.110
to ICS/SCADA which is industrial
control systems, all right?

44
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:12.700
>> All the way to bullet proof vests.

45
00:02:12.700 --> 00:02:13.270
>> Yeah.

46
00:02:13.270 --> 00:02:15.045
>> It's really cool,
they get to shoot people.

47
00:02:15.045 --> 00:02:16.880
>> [LAUGH] Man.

48
00:02:16.880 --> 00:02:21.990
So NIST is actually responsible for
a lot of what drives government standards.

49
00:02:21.990 --> 00:02:28.370
Now, with that being said, we need to take
a look at what 171 is specific around.

50
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:33.130
And that really is the protection
of controlled information for

51
00:02:33.130 --> 00:02:35.350
unclassified systems.

52
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:41.640
And that is around non-federal,
it is around information systems.

53
00:02:41.640 --> 00:02:43.480
So basically, go ahead Josh.

54
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:46.170
>> What we're talking about is you've
got to pull the important terms out

55
00:02:46.170 --> 00:02:46.970
of that title.

56
00:02:46.970 --> 00:02:49.530
Okay, the full title of NIST 800-171 is

57
00:02:49.530 --> 00:02:52.570
Protecting Controlled Unclassified
Information, CUI, by the way is

58
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:58.220
the abbreviation, in Non-federal
Information Systems and Organizations.

59
00:02:58.220 --> 00:03:02.616
Okay, so it's protecting information
that's not in a classification scheme, for

60
00:03:02.616 --> 00:03:04.370
non-federal agencies.

61
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:07.120
Why would NIST care about that?

62
00:03:07.120 --> 00:03:08.070
>> I don't know.

63
00:03:08.070 --> 00:03:09.470
Why would NIST care about that?

64
00:03:09.470 --> 00:03:14.460
Really what we're looking at the access,
we're looking at security requirements

65
00:03:14.460 --> 00:03:20.060
based around access control,
based around identity and authentication.

66
00:03:20.060 --> 00:03:21.600
Based around incident response and

67
00:03:21.600 --> 00:03:25.510
maintenance, based around
personnel security.

68
00:03:25.510 --> 00:03:28.830
>> So Scott, this looks like a serious
information security program, and

69
00:03:28.830 --> 00:03:29.820
a fairly complete one.

70
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:31.500
>> Yeah.
>> You've got all the identification,

71
00:03:31.500 --> 00:03:34.490
you got the accountability,
you've got all the training,

72
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:37.690
sort of every piece of a information
security program is here.

73
00:03:37.690 --> 00:03:41.060
But this is specifically for
non-federal agencies and

74
00:03:41.060 --> 00:03:43.870
organizations for
unclassified information.

75
00:03:43.870 --> 00:03:47.030
I mean, who does this apply to?

76
00:03:47.030 --> 00:03:50.580
>> Well, it applies a lot to companies
that wanna do business with the federal

77
00:03:50.580 --> 00:03:52.460
government, right?

78
00:03:52.460 --> 00:03:58.600
So the real question is, Josh,
if I may, why do I care, right?

79
00:03:58.600 --> 00:04:04.730
Well, why I care is because either I
have to be a part of DFARS, right?

80
00:04:04.730 --> 00:04:05.470
>> What's DFARS?

81
00:04:05.470 --> 00:04:09.500
>> DFARS,
the DOD Federal Acquisition Resource?

82
00:04:09.500 --> 00:04:10.190
>> Regulations.

83
00:04:10.190 --> 00:04:14.470
>> Regulations, or FARS,
the Federal Acquisition Regulations.

84
00:04:14.470 --> 00:04:15.240
Thank you.

85
00:04:15.240 --> 00:04:19.180
Am I a government contractor because,
guess what, I care.

86
00:04:19.180 --> 00:04:25.700
Am I sub to a sub to a sub to a sub,
I still have to deal with 171, right?

87
00:04:25.700 --> 00:04:29.680
But the question I say is, why not 27001?

88
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:34.422
>> Well because 27001 is incredibly
particular it's a detailed-oriented

89
00:04:34.422 --> 00:04:35.419
beyond belief.

90
00:04:35.419 --> 00:04:39.821
800-171 is a significant
amount easier than ISO 27001.

91
00:04:39.821 --> 00:04:42.295
It's a little more far reaching, but

92
00:04:42.295 --> 00:04:47.020
ISO 27001 is the OCD cousin
of 800171 if you will.

93
00:04:47.020 --> 00:04:50.435
So it also is a nice stepping stone it
helps you build to the next cyber security

94
00:04:50.435 --> 00:04:51.442
framework, the CSL.

95
00:04:51.442 --> 00:04:55.380
So effectively, if you care about this
you're either a government contractor,

96
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:59.504
you're a government sub to a contractor,
or sub to a government contractor rather.

97
00:04:59.504 --> 00:05:02.202
You need to prove that
you're following a risk

98
00:05:02.202 --> 00:05:04.630
management program of some sort, okay?

99
00:05:04.630 --> 00:05:07.450
For a sale, for a customer,
for a supplier, for

100
00:05:07.450 --> 00:05:09.940
a regulatory regime of some sort.

101
00:05:09.940 --> 00:05:12.450
And you go, you know, 800 one
something one doesn't sound so bad.

102
00:05:12.450 --> 00:05:16.950
It's understandable those families
of controls that we just looked at

103
00:05:16.950 --> 00:05:21.090
are totally literally realistic,
they're reasonable.

104
00:05:21.090 --> 00:05:26.810
>> They are and so 171 actually
breaks down the four main steps and

105
00:05:26.810 --> 00:05:30.760
those are Review, Implement,
Analyze, and Audit.

106
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:32.740
>> Okay, so
let's talk about each of them real quick.

107
00:05:32.740 --> 00:05:33.360
>> Yeah.

108
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:36.488
>> So in Review,
you're gonna go over what you have now.

109
00:05:36.488 --> 00:05:40.898
You're gonna see, hey I'm right here,
and you're going to go, hum,

110
00:05:40.898 --> 00:05:43.070
they need me to be over here.

111
00:05:43.070 --> 00:05:45.920
So how do I get from A to B?

112
00:05:45.920 --> 00:05:46.960
And that's implement.

113
00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:48.830
This leads to each other very very nicely.

114
00:05:48.830 --> 00:05:49.840
>> It does.

115
00:05:49.840 --> 00:05:51.070
>> So
you're going to review what you have.

116
00:05:51.070 --> 00:05:54.260
You're going to review what you are,
your business process, and your CUI.

117
00:05:54.260 --> 00:05:56.740
In other words,
what information do I have?

118
00:05:56.740 --> 00:06:01.480
That's data classification, that's
managing your assets, asset inventory.

119
00:06:01.480 --> 00:06:04.610
That's knowing who has
access to those assets.

120
00:06:04.610 --> 00:06:09.510
That's understanding your business
processes around those assets,

121
00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:11.880
around that date,
around those classifications.

122
00:06:11.880 --> 00:06:14.240
And then realizing that I have a gap,
I have a risk,

123
00:06:14.240 --> 00:06:16.780
I have a problem I need to fix that.

124
00:06:16.780 --> 00:06:20.940
So, I'm gonna implement some controls,
some segmentation, some new processes.

125
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:25.870
Modify the existing ones or
whatever, and then.

126
00:06:25.870 --> 00:06:27.810
>> We're gonna step right in to analyze.

127
00:06:27.810 --> 00:06:31.720
So let's make sure that we've done
our review correctly, we've done our

128
00:06:31.720 --> 00:06:35.800
implementation correctly, which really
leads us to a controls gap, right?

129
00:06:35.800 --> 00:06:39.550
So where are we, where are we headed and
how do we get there right?

130
00:06:39.550 --> 00:06:43.230
And that's really your gap, that's where
a good gap analysis comes into place.

131
00:06:43.230 --> 00:06:45.710
>> Well, right, and so
then we've done our review.

132
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:49.090
We've implemented to fix the gap,
we've analyzed to make sure that we fixed

133
00:06:49.090 --> 00:06:52.510
the gap, this is basically the double
check, and then we're gonna audit.

134
00:06:52.510 --> 00:06:55.580
And the audit is gonna be where we say,
we are actually in compliance,

135
00:06:55.580 --> 00:07:00.740
we are validating, we are verifying,
we are making sure we're doing it right.

136
00:07:00.740 --> 00:07:05.060
>> But the audit also comes into play
when trying to deal with your road map.

137
00:07:05.060 --> 00:07:11.530
The roadmap basically says, how we're
going to implement the entire solution.

138
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:15.140
When you audit, it's not that
you're auditing for a compliance.

139
00:07:15.140 --> 00:07:19.630
Sure, that might be something
gained to help your business but,

140
00:07:19.630 --> 00:07:22.830
at the same time, you're really auditing,
and a lot of companies miss this,

141
00:07:22.830 --> 00:07:26.190
you're auditing to make sure that
you're matching your roadmap.

142
00:07:26.190 --> 00:07:28.144
>> Well agreed, agreed.

143
00:07:28.144 --> 00:07:33.295
So your road map, or your strategic
road map really, says that I want to be,

144
00:07:33.295 --> 00:07:38.280
let's say, I wanna have 5000 new
customers by the end of the year.

145
00:07:38.280 --> 00:07:41.790
Those customers are gonna be in
the government space, those customers

146
00:07:41.790 --> 00:07:46.340
are gonna want me to be certified or
at least secure in some form or fashion.

147
00:07:46.340 --> 00:07:49.726
We're gonna use 800-171 to show them that
we have a risk management framework.

148
00:07:49.726 --> 00:07:53.015
To get 800-171, we're going to make
sure that we've done our gap analysis,

149
00:07:53.015 --> 00:07:55.665
we're gonna make sure that we've analyzed,
we've implemented,

150
00:07:55.665 --> 00:07:57.001
we've taken care of everything.

151
00:07:57.001 --> 00:08:00.503
We're gonna use this as a stepping stone
in that road map to get all those new

152
00:08:00.503 --> 00:08:04.075
customers, to get all that new business,
to get all those things going on.

153
00:08:04.075 --> 00:08:06.490
Okay, so the government has come down and

154
00:08:06.490 --> 00:08:10.490
said that all DOD contractors
must be 171 compliant by what?

155
00:08:10.490 --> 00:08:12.870
December 31st?

156
00:08:12.870 --> 00:08:13.370
>> 2017.
>> Of 2017, right.

157
00:08:13.370 --> 00:08:13.920
So

158
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:17.862
my real question to you is how
does this relate to our business?

159
00:08:17.862 --> 00:08:18.535
>> That easy.

160
00:08:18.535 --> 00:08:20.185
Are you a government contractor?

161
00:08:20.185 --> 00:08:22.105
Are you a sub to a government contractor?

162
00:08:22.105 --> 00:08:24.105
Are you a sub to a sub to a sub to a sub?

163
00:08:24.105 --> 00:08:26.755
Are you anywhere in
the supplier value chain?

164
00:08:26.755 --> 00:08:28.626
Those terms by the way mean
roughly the same thing,

165
00:08:28.626 --> 00:08:30.814
it's just different people
use them differently, okay?

166
00:08:30.814 --> 00:08:34.765
If you are a supplier, if you are the
person actually doing the work, if you

167
00:08:34.765 --> 00:08:39.000
are a customer, that is a value chain
from supplier to processor to customer.

168
00:08:39.000 --> 00:08:42.088
If you're in that value chain anywhere,
and by the way, there's are more,

169
00:08:42.088 --> 00:08:45.740
there's what,
6,000 subcontractors to the government?

170
00:08:45.740 --> 00:08:47.510
>> There's a lot.

171
00:08:47.510 --> 00:08:49.360
>> So if there's 6,000
subcontractors to the government,

172
00:08:49.360 --> 00:08:51.990
how many subcontractors do they have?

173
00:08:51.990 --> 00:08:53.720
Dear God, the number is huge.

174
00:08:53.720 --> 00:08:56.690
Now, there's also other
reasons to use 800-171, or

175
00:08:56.690 --> 00:08:58.360
any good risk management framework.

176
00:08:58.360 --> 00:09:00.350
Do you wanna reduce your sales friction?

177
00:09:00.350 --> 00:09:04.150
If you go, hey,
I'd like to sign up for ITPro.TV and

178
00:09:04.150 --> 00:09:05.700
I wanna give you my credit card.

179
00:09:05.700 --> 00:09:09.210
And they go, hey, we have managed to
secure your credit card information

180
00:09:09.210 --> 00:09:14.470
because we are PCI compliant or
using a PCI compliant payment processor,

181
00:09:14.470 --> 00:09:16.600
you go, hey, I feel better about this.

182
00:09:16.600 --> 00:09:19.210
I feel better about putting my
credit card in those little boxes

183
00:09:19.210 --> 00:09:22.500
because I know that they're doing
it in a secure fashion, okay?

184
00:09:22.500 --> 00:09:25.100
And that's how you get it,
you reduce sales friction.

185
00:09:25.100 --> 00:09:28.160
If somebody said, hey, would you mind
mailing me, snail mailing me, or faxing

186
00:09:28.160 --> 00:09:31.900
me, that's fine, just send me a copy of
your credit card, would you feel secure?

187
00:09:31.900 --> 00:09:32.880
Cuz I know I wouldn't.

188
00:09:32.880 --> 00:09:38.060
>> Right, so how does this affect your
DFARS and your FARS standing, right?

189
00:09:38.060 --> 00:09:42.660
As a federal resource
we need to figure out

190
00:09:42.660 --> 00:09:47.730
the easiest way to move all of this
forward and still be compliant, right?

191
00:09:47.730 --> 00:09:52.813
So understanding your contracting
officer and what their technical

192
00:09:52.813 --> 00:09:58.958
requirements are according to the FARS and
the DFARS will really help with 171.

193
00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:04.875
Because originally we used to have to deal
with 853 which was [INAUDIBLE] as what,

194
00:10:04.875 --> 00:10:06.489
ISO 27000
>> 1 and 2.

195
00:10:06.489 --> 00:10:10.940
>> 1 and 2, right.
So we've taken the medium listing for 853,

196
00:10:10.940 --> 00:10:15.020
sprinkled in some ISO 27000 1 and 2, and

197
00:10:15.020 --> 00:10:19.696
that's how we got to 171
>> Right so they're a little off topic,

198
00:10:19.696 --> 00:10:22.220
but there's a little bit more to that.

199
00:10:22.220 --> 00:10:24.730
>> Yeah.
>> And the reason is that 853 is a pre

200
00:10:24.730 --> 00:10:25.670
scriptive standard.

201
00:10:25.670 --> 00:10:28.995
853 says you will do this,
and this, and this.

202
00:10:28.995 --> 00:10:34.030
800-171 is a descriptive standard, it says
it will protect against these attacks.

203
00:10:34.030 --> 00:10:37.550
How you do it is up to you, because these
things change on, well, let's be honest,

204
00:10:37.550 --> 00:10:38.430
a daily basis.

205
00:10:38.430 --> 00:10:39.170
>> They do.

206
00:10:39.170 --> 00:10:42.110
>> But if you are protected
against these types of attacks,

207
00:10:42.110 --> 00:10:43.540
you are following the standard.

208
00:10:43.540 --> 00:10:48.400
>> Okay, okay, so seeing that we're
protected against these types of attacks,

209
00:10:48.400 --> 00:10:51.730
right The real question is do I have
to change the business process?

210
00:10:51.730 --> 00:10:52.300
>> No.

211
00:10:52.300 --> 00:10:53.490
>> Because a lot of what we do,

212
00:10:53.490 --> 00:10:57.910
a lot of what we do and
a lot of what we say is that no matter

213
00:10:57.910 --> 00:11:02.130
what you do as far as complain goes you
have to tailor to the business, right?

214
00:11:02.130 --> 00:11:07.530
So do do we change business process,
maybe, right.

215
00:11:08.570 --> 00:11:09.400
>> It might be.

216
00:11:09.400 --> 00:11:13.790
But the thing is, here's the thing,
it depends on your security maturity.

217
00:11:13.790 --> 00:11:17.610
It depends on your existing processes, it
depends on your risk management framework.

218
00:11:17.610 --> 00:11:19.330
If you're not using risk management,

219
00:11:19.330 --> 00:11:21.770
if you don't have existing
business processes.

220
00:11:21.770 --> 00:11:25.460
If you don't have a high enough security
maturity, or any information security

221
00:11:25.460 --> 00:11:28.700
maturity, physical security
maturity all these different types.

222
00:11:28.700 --> 00:11:31.710
Then yeah, you're gonna probably have to
change some of your business processes.

223
00:11:31.710 --> 00:11:34.360
If you've already built up a very,
very secure,

224
00:11:34.360 --> 00:11:39.310
very mature system of information physical
security, and you've got risk management,

225
00:11:39.310 --> 00:11:41.150
you're doing risk-based thinking.

226
00:11:41.150 --> 00:11:44.000
You're saying, I've got an asset
worth $1,000, I'm spending $500 for

227
00:11:44.000 --> 00:11:48.760
protection, I'm protected up to this
level, you're risk thinking, okay?

228
00:11:48.760 --> 00:11:49.640
You're thinking about your risk.

229
00:11:49.640 --> 00:11:50.240
>> Right.
>> You're probably

230
00:11:50.240 --> 00:11:53.660
won't have to change your processes at all
or not very much, maybe a little tiny bit.

231
00:11:53.660 --> 00:11:57.450
>> So if we go onto the next,
we're asking just a simple question here.

00:11:57.450 --> 00:11:58.850

00:11:58.850 --> 00:12:04.740
Is there a certifying body for 171 that's

234
00:12:04.740 --> 00:12:10.090

235
00:12:10.090 --> 00:12:14.193
>> So the contractors, remember we're

236
00:12:14.193 --> 00:12:17.731
they're sort of the main receiving body or

237
00:12:17.731 --> 00:12:21.507
The government contractors have no

00:12:21.507 --> 00:12:25.392

241
00:12:32.081 --> 00:12:35.115

242
00:12:35.115 --> 00:12:38.870
there's no real way to get that stamp of

243
00:12:38.870 --> 00:12:43.089
So it's a problem,
that's a real problem, you don't know.

00:12:43.089 --> 00:12:45.694

245
00:12:45.694 --> 00:12:48.556
according to our paperwork,

00:12:48.556 --> 00:12:51.061
But just like anybody can say,

00:12:51.061 --> 00:12:52.540
we didn't see a problem there.

00:12:52.540 --> 00:12:55.300
Well, I do in my interpretation
of the standards, and

00:12:55.300 --> 00:12:57.100
that's where the problem arises.

00:13:03.620 --> 00:13:04.240
>> It is.

00:13:04.240 --> 00:13:05.410

00:13:09.940 --> 00:13:10.580

00:13:56.320 --> 00:13:59.540
Okay, this, I should be very honest and

00:13:59.540 --> 00:14:03.070

00:14:03.070 --> 00:14:09.060
There is no one god given way to do this,

275
00:14:09.060 --> 00:14:12.490
We like to do a gap analysis because we
believe that we don't know how much it's

276
00:14:12.490 --> 00:14:14.860
gonna cost until we know
where you stand right now.

277
00:14:14.860 --> 00:14:17.450
We already know what the regulations
say you have to do and be and

278
00:14:17.450 --> 00:14:19.810
where you have to end up.

279
00:14:19.810 --> 00:14:21.190
But we don't know where you are now.

280
00:14:21.190 --> 00:14:23.960
So unless we know that how
can we tell you the cost?

281
00:14:23.960 --> 00:14:27.060
So we tend to do a gap analysis that takes
anywhere from two to four weeks, and

282
00:14:27.060 --> 00:14:29.324
costs somewhere between 10 and $50,000.

283
00:14:29.324 --> 00:14:34.496
All right, that's on site, offsite,
interviews, investigation,

284
00:14:34.496 --> 00:14:38.497
VOM scans, all kinds of scans,
and look-ats, okay?

285
00:14:38.497 --> 00:14:40.855
Then we can tell you,
here's your remediation plan,

286
00:14:40.855 --> 00:14:43.810
you can do these parts yourself and
these parts we can help you with.

287
00:14:43.810 --> 00:14:45.280
This is what it's gonna cost, etc.

288
00:14:45.280 --> 00:14:47.700
>> That's where the roadmap
comes into play.

289
00:14:47.700 --> 00:14:48.310
>> Right.

290
00:14:48.310 --> 00:14:52.840
>> So from the remediation plan and

291
00:14:52.840 --> 00:14:56.780

that's how you build out your roadmap.

292
00:14:56.780 --> 00:14:59.760
Once you've gone through your roadmap and
you've done your

293
00:15:00.920 --> 00:15:05.770
Audit on the backend of the roadmap, then
we come in and do a reassessment, right?

294
00:15:05.770 --> 00:15:08.150
>> So
this goes back to what we were saying.

295
00:15:08.150 --> 00:15:12.180
It's a gap analysis,
then it's a remediation,

296
00:15:12.180 --> 00:15:16.760
then it's reassess and it goes
through a full step and you iterate.

297
00:15:16.760 --> 00:15:18.537
Think of this almost as like
agile compliance, okay?

298
00:15:20.160 --> 00:15:23.200
You do a Gap analysis,
you figure out what your backlog is.

299
00:15:23.200 --> 00:15:25.750
You do your remediation, which is
when you're actually doing the work,

300
00:15:25.750 --> 00:15:29.610
you're doing sprints, and with
800-171 you can do a sprint at a time.

301
00:15:29.610 --> 00:15:31.690
You can do multiple sprints,
it all depends.

302
00:15:31.690 --> 00:15:34.240
And then you do a reassess, which is
where you do the stand up meeting and go,

303
00:15:34.240 --> 00:15:36.560
how did we do, okay?

304
00:15:36.560 --> 00:15:38.350
So it's almost like agile compliance.

305
00:15:38.350 --> 00:15:42.100
And we prefer to do it that way rather
than a waterfall compliance method.

306
00:15:42.100 --> 00:15:44.460
I'm bastardizing a little bit,
bear with me.

307
00:15:44.460 --> 00:15:45.712
Because at waterfall compliance,

we're gonna charge you a quarter of

00:15:48.460 --> 00:15:49.310
Well, I don't know that.

00:15:49.310 --> 00:15:51.930
It might cost $70000 and
be able to do everything.

00:15:51.930 --> 00:15:53.630
It might cost a half a million dollars and

00:15:53.630 --> 00:15:55.536
those other guys are gonna
short change you.

We prefer to do in a step by step basis
because it also helps to make the budget
